div.head: Publishing and Women in Movement
div.p: I’ve had some very happy times in Edmonton, not least when Rudy Wiebe and I launched his now classic book written with Yvonne Johnston, Stolen Life: The Journey of A Cree Woman, and somehow, due to Rudy’s unusual contacts in high and low places, we held a full-scale media book launch inside the prison for Native women. It was an important occasion, giving recognition to the women of the prison who participated in the full Native ceremony honouring one woman’s courage in telling her story. It was also a transformative moment for women and a telling moment for me as a publisher since the book’s success nationwide and as a Governor General’s Award winner underlined our need to tell the stories of our country—not least through the eyes and experiences of women.

Publishing, writing, and the power of new media are critical components in our fast-transforming world. And in Canada it is especially fast changing if you consider that only thirty-odd years ago, this country played almost no role on the international publishing stage, few of our writers were recognized globally, and all struggled to reach audiences beyond our borders. Today, myriad Canadian writers are acclaimed and honoured, translated in every country. To help picture how this came about, I will offer here a couple of stories about this change that I’ve witnessed personally. They both reflect the importance of imagination in achieving far-reaching change: they tell us something about courage, and how we effect change; and how we use our stories—whether in fiction, non-fiction, poetry, whether in print or electronically—to speak to others, and for others, to that end.

The first story is about publishing in movement and the second is about women’s writing in movement. In the 1980s, a conference titled women in movement would have had a specific feminist agenda—and with good reason. Those reasons need no naming today, and are not altogether gone. But in many parts of the world they still hold medieval sway. So I will bring us around at the end to a remarkable online campaign that I and a few friends helped create in July 2010 to try to stop the death by stoning of a woman accused of adultery in Iran, Sakineh Ashtiani—which you will have read about, if the digital world is working!—because for me the threads come together in that final story. The first is a story about how and why Canadian writing suddenly leapt to prominence on the world stage during the 1970s and 1980s, rather like Venus leaping out of her shell onto the beach. The power and appeal of Canadian writing has grown so swiftly internationally since then that it’s taken us from being widely seen as a largely colonial backwater to the centre of the world stage, with a globally valued national literature. I’ve been lucky enough to have witnessed it, and to play a small part in the battles.

Imagine it is 1996 and you are at the autumnal Frankfurt Book Fair, which is the fast-beating heart of international publishing. The annual fair has been in existence since the fourteenth century, and publishers from all countries meet there each year to do the business of publishing. It’s a bazaar, a souk—thousands of excited publishers buying and selling the country-rights to their authors’ works. It’s the largest trade fair in that city of year-long trade fairs, with the automotive industry in second place—which is notable. That year, I was there for one of the first great moments for Canadian new fiction. Knopf Canada had just published four remarkable first novels in a literary program, the New Face of Fiction, which I’d created to support new fictional voices. We were celebrating Gail Anderson Dargatz, who at that time worked and lived on a farm outside Millett, and was just taking the country by storm with her beautiful first novel, The Cure for Death By Lightning, while Ann-Marie MacDonald was being feted for winning the Commonwealth Prize for the best work of fiction for her first novel, Fall on Your Knees, and Dionne Brand (who would become Toronto’s poet laureate) was being feted for her luminous first novel. In Canada, we all know the depth of our writing talent; but to see the excitement at Frankfurt that year for these unknowns from Canada was exhilarating. It was a scrum, with publishers from Japan to Sweden bidding for the rights of first-time novelists (though, it must be said, Yann Martel’s experimental first novel Self rather struggled to find publishers, but some did see in it the power of imagination that would soon produce Life of Pi). Ten years later, when I returned to the Frankfurt Book Fair , publishers from thirty-six countries would gather to celebrate the simultaneous publication in all languages—a first in history—of one book, Margaret Atwood’s Penelopiad, which was being heralded by the Sunday Times as the most exciting retelling of Homer’s Odyssey in generations; and later that week, I would find myself addressing another roomful of foreign publishers who had come together to celebrate Miriam Toews and the translations of her brilliant, dark, funny, endearing novel, A Complicated Kindness. Much had changed in that one decade. Today, newspapers in all parts of the world headline the appeal and power of Canadian writers, and Alice Munro is the 2013 Nobel laureate, but you’d be hard pressed to find headlines quoting a Canadian politician or referencing a major trade deal or important international situation in which Canada had played a role.

p.ref: The fact is, for the most part, Canada’s profile abroad is its culture. It’s an extraordinary success story. But it didn’t come about easily. It was only a short time ago that Canadian writers were struggling dismally to be recognized abroad. So it’s intriguing to look at why Canadian writers have found such a welcome internationally. Was it the priceless early investments in the arts, province by province and federally, now largely mourned and buried? Was it simply made possible by the newly developed strengths of publishing businesses in Canada? Was it the undoubted merit of the writing? It’s a combination of factors, of course, a partnership, in which the community, its citizens, its universities, its businesses, its politicians, have all played essential roles, many hands helping to nurture the shining results we see today in the books we read and love. Anybody who thinks that what has happened in Canadian publishing is the result of a handful of good writers appearing all of a sudden, out of the blue, has completely missed the investments of the last forty years.

div.p: In 1972, when I was fortunate enough to come to Canada, publishing—books and magazines—was a small industry. Canada was still a cultural colony as far as England was concerned, and a slightly backward northern state as far as the United States was concerned. I mean that literally. In international publishing contracts the English automatically claimed Canada as their territory, while the Americans simultaneously claimed us too. We were like a bone being fought over by two dogs. And they chose not to understand why Canadian publishers and writers found this irritating and stultifying for the development of our own ideas, our own businesses. A full two decades earlier, the lawyer-poet F.R. Scott, who understood the importance of giving the writers of the nation a voice, had struggled against this: Is Canada, he asked, to remain a hewer of wood and drawer of water for her richer and more powerful neighbours, first Britain and then America forever? In 1957, when the writer Dave Godfrey, the founder of the House of Anansi along with the great poet Dennis Lee, famously asked the University of Toronto when it would set up a course in Canadian Literature, he was told, Maybe in ten years—if the right people die. Well, some of the right people did die. But mostly, the writers wanted out, wanted their voices heard. In the decade following Canada’s Centennial year, when a surge of cultural, nationalist feeling swept the country, a few inspired, inspiring alternative small presses dedicated to Canadian literature sprang up, run by the rebellious writers themselves to give voice to those feelingsin Edmonton, radical NeWest Press with George Melnyk and Douglas Barbour and then Rudy Wiebe, Robert Kroetsch, and Aritha van Herk; Mel Hurtig, who later gave us our first national encyclopedia, went from bookseller to publisher; in BC, Talonbooks and Pulp Press; in Ontario, Coach House Press (whose proud motto was Printed in Canada by Mindless Acid Freaks), which first published Michael Ondaatje, bp Nichol, and then, in 1972, the House of Anansi published Survival—which, to the astonishment of the twenty-three-year-old Margaret Atwood herself, became a major Canadian bestseller—a fierce, challenging, funny, activist essay that reflected the ferment of social and cultural ideas boiling up all around. These were the seedbeds of our new literary culture.:

p.ref: But while what was happening was irrepressible in its creative strength, very few writers could make a living or even sustain themselves on their writing. In 1967, domestic sales of Canadian books were barely $200 million (by 1997, they would be over $2 billion; to put that in perspective, ten years later, that had more than doubled). There were very few large Canadian publishing houses—above all, McClelland and Stewart with the charismatic Jack at the helm, and Clarke Irwin with the teetotalling Clarkes and Irwins, and the indomitable Mrs. Clarke setting out to create a solid base for Canadian literature in schools.

div.p: It was a tough battle that amazing generation fought, defying the odds—that generation before mine. An exciting time—marked, it seems when you talk to the protagonists, as much by a great deal of alcohol, fraught love affairs, and broken marriages as by good writing or publishing.

But the books we loved, then as now, were those that showed us who we are, gave shape to our hearts, to the challenges and mysteries of life, and gave voice to the familiar places we call home: in Alberta, the incomparable and beloved W.O. Mitchell and Rudy Wiebe; in Ontario, Timothy Findley and Robertson Davies; in Quebec, Nicole Brossard and Marie-Claire Blais.

But through the sixties, seventies, and even the eighties, the creative ferment wasn’t making its way outside our borders. The problem largely was that the power structure was colonial. The British publishers, like the Americans, who sold their own books into Canada for gain, had no interest in taking home the colonial literature of Canada. But the big world market was the blood that many of our writers craved—and also needed in order to make a living. Rare exceptions—such as Lucy Maud Montgomery—had made it out of Canada in significant numbers. You could count on the fingers of one hand the writers whose books travelled: the young Margaret Laurence and younger Alice Munro; Mavis Gallant (living in Paris); Mordecai Richler (living in London then).

I’ve been truly lucky to work with some of our finest writers, men and women, including Michael Ondaatje, Miriam Toews, Margaret Atwood, or internationally, Toni Morrison, Jeanette Winterson, P.D. James. But you can imagine a nerdy bookworm of twenty-two back then, as I was, arriving in the middle of all this fledgling cultural excitement. Growing up in England, I was completely unaware of Canadian writers, Oxford education notwithstanding. But I loved stories, and I took the first job I could get in a publishing house: Clarke Irwin. I began as a coffee girl and made the steep climb up the ladder to editorial assistant, and finally, just before I left, Bill Clarke made me an assistant editor. But at that age, movement is never fast enough. I wanted to publish the writers I liked, and to do it quickly. So I began my own small publishing house, with nothing to go on but the confidence of the innocent, a transcendent love of literature, a belief in the power of the book to help shape the world, and two brave authors who had failed to find a publisher and were both desperate enough and generous enough to sign up with a kid crammed into the dusty backroom of a second-hand bookstore.

I was lucky to arrive then because the tough battles to make a mark within Canada had already been fought by that first brilliant wave of publishers and writers. My aggravation was that the doors of the wider publishing world were closed against us—often literally closed in our faces. It was hard to get an appointment in New York or London, the centres of publishing then. It was dispiriting, sometimes humiliating. But youthful passion needs very little in the way of sustenance, and I believed then, as now, that we have not only a unique Canadian voice but a voice that speaks uniquely to the world.

p.ref: One day I borrowed money from equally penniless but supportive friends to make the trip to New York—and went knocking on the doors of world publishing, clutching a manuscript by one of my two authors in the hope of finding a publisher for it there. I remember how terrified I was, when I actually stood in the doorway of the famous house of Alfred A. Knopf on Fifty-Fourth Street. I’d never even been to New York before, but—ironically, considering I ended up twenty years later founding Knopf in Canada—I’d decided I might as well start at the top. Of course I found out, having come all that way on borrowed funds, that the grand editor with whom I’d made an appointment had already cancelled it and passed me on to an underling. But I was lucky again. It was his young assistant’s first week too, and she saw my face—I was clearly about to burst into tears—and took pity on me: we went out and had many drinks in the Oyster Bar on her boss’s tab, and she went back clutching the manuscript and convinced the grand editor to read it, and shortly thereafter our Canadian-Czech writer Josef Škvorecký had an American deal for his novel The Bass Saxophone, which would soon be acclaimed by the New Yorker as the greatest jazz novel ever written.

div.p: That was a scene repeated a few months later in London, when the venerable house of the Hogarth Press—founded by Virginia and Leonard Woolf—called on Christmas Day to accept a manuscript I’d dropped off by the poet Richard Outram. And so on. Early forays to open doors, the beginning of a concerted effort by a handful of determined young publishers and supportive writers, and by the early festivals such as the International Authors’ Festival at Harbourfront. Until, in 1984, when I led the first Canadian Publishing Trade Mission to London, the headline about the event, in the business section of the London Times read, to our great delight, The Empire Strikes Back. The Brits had got the message.

ref.ref: Today, Canadian literature is published, sold, read, acclaimed, and taught around the world. I must be clear: most writers do not shine in the sun but work in obscurity and exist on poverty-level incomes. But never before have our domestic book sales had the potential to be so high, with our expectation for a major hardcover bestseller not being the 5,000 copies that it was just ten years ago, but more like 15,000 or 20,000 or even 60,000 or 80,000 in Canada. Internationally, Miriam Toews’s A Complicated Kindness, for instance, has sold over half a million copies. Ann-Marie MacDonald’s Fall on Your Knees is at well over two million, thanks to the power of Oprah. Yann Martel’s luminous Life of Pi, one of five Canadian novels to walk away with the Booker Prize, and has now sold almost 900,000 copies in Canada and over nine million around the world.

p.ref: Our stories, our arts—that is largely what people think of when they think of Canada. People elsewhere see and understand Canada through our writers. We have a voice, an image, on the world’s stage that has broad benefits for our writers, our communities and cities, and unexpected political and business implications. When it comes time for Canada to buy or to negotiate, the attitude towards Canada and the kind of people we are has been determined to a surprising extent by the projection of our culture abroad. In the digital borderless world, it will be more important than ever to find ways to cherish and sustain that, and easier to project it.

div.p: So what is it in our society, in our values, that makes our writing—our fiction and our non-fiction—so appealing and sexy to the world at large? The answer, I think, lies somewhere off to the side.

p.ref: The novelist and essayist Pico Iyer called Canada’s literature the most exciting in the English-speaking world, and he places the cause firmly in what he calls our mongrel society. He pointed out that many of the finest writers in English are now men and women with names like Salman Rushdie, Rohinton Mistry, Anita Rau Badami, M.G. Vassanji, Chimamanda Adichie, Jumpha Lahiri, and Michael Ondaatje. And that many of these writers come from Canada. The power of Anglo-Saxon literature has been taken over by a literature that springs from the old colonial margins.

ref.ref: There’s something about our marginal, mongrel status that forms a particular type of writer whose sense of social justice and injustice, of humanity and inhumanity is keen. You become a particularly capable, acute observer if you live long in the margins. Ours is now a literature written by people from many diverse cultures that have been distilled into the Canadian culture. To draw from a lovely phrase of Anne Michaels, our writers at their best put together shattered pieces to make a stained-glass whole. Or, as Rudy Wiebe said on receiving the Governor General’s Award for fiction, It is only the stories we tell each other that will make us a true Canadian people.

p.ref: The historical lesson is plain: when we look at the greatness of Rome or Greece, or Alexandria, do we think of their business record? It is our writers, our artists, our scientists, and our philosophers—and sometimes their patrons—that make known the character of a nation. It is only the societies that have paid their dues to their arts that are remembered and glorified. But the rewards are not just in some far-off future. They begin in the present, when our own people as well as the world at large hears the voice of Canada through its writers and its artists, sits up, pays attention, and comes knocking on our doors. As they are knocking today.

div.p: If our writers are touching the centre of the world now, it is to some degree because we speak from knowledge of the margins—messy, intolerant, dominated and rebellious, confused and optimistic, as the margins are wont to be. As is much of the world today. And that understanding out of the margins, from the sidelines and the alleyways, brings us to the second story, because it is, I believe, the very thing that has been moving a certain aspect of women’s writing in a fascinating new direction.

Let me start with reading you a quote from that wise, tough-minded woman, Virginia Woolf, in her essay A Room of One’s Own—we think we know everything about her and then, like Margaret Atwood, she becomes prophetic in unexpected ways.

ref.ref: Not quite one hundred years ago—1928—Virginia Woolf exhorted mothers to provide their daughters with money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction. And what else could they do but write fiction? she asks, in that very cool, clever essay, since the only training that a woman had…was…in the observation of character, in the analysis of emotion. Her sensibility had been educated for centuries by the influences of the common sitting room. People’s feelings were impressed upon her; personal relations were always before her eyes. Therefore, when the middle-class woman took to writing, she naturally wrote novels (61). When Virginia looks around her: I find no noble sentiments about…influencing the world to higher ends.…Do not dream, she says wryly, of influencing other people (100). She hoped that women might attain that influence within a hundred years. For if we live another century or so and have five hundred [pounds] a year each of us and rooms of our own; if we can get out of the common sitting room, and have the habit of freedom and the courage to write exactly what we think; if we see human beings not always in relation to each other but in relation to reality; and the sky too, and the trees or whatever it may be in themselves; if we face the fact that our relation is to the world of reality and not only to the world of men and women, then the opportunity will come.… It calls for gigantic courage and strength. More than anything, perhaps…it calls for confidence in oneself. (102, 31) Well, we’re there, and just ahead of her estimated century.

There’s still an argument about it, but those who argue are those who like flogging dead donkeys. In November 2008, The Independent(UK) titled a discussion piece about how there seems to be a lack of women non-fiction writers Why Don’t Women Write Big Ideas Books? Julia Cheiffetz, a senior editor at HarperCollins, not a position of minor influence, in a 2008 piece in the Huffington Post called What the Hell, Malcolm Gladwell, responded to the absence of women in Gladwell’s book Outliers: It’s hard to know whether women are better at telling stories than propagating ideas…or whether the intellectual audacity required to sell our hypotheses about the world simply isn’t in our genetic makeup. But the tides of change have swept over her. While twenty, even fifteen years ago, the many manuscripts from women that crossed my desk were largely fiction. Even then much of the non-fiction was world-changing for readers in its power. From Rachel Carson to Jane Jacobs, a great Canadian whom I published and counted a friend, we’ve been blessed with great non-fiction women writers. Their books have been gigantic building blocks for all humankind. But still, fifteen years ago I received comparatively few manuscripts by women that embraced Big Ideas, tackled head-on society’s major concerns, politics, economics, human rights, strove to influence and change the world directly and overtly. But today many of the most passionately raised voices in the world are women’s voices, dealing with broad human issues with sensibility, empathy, and activism, speaking in much needed voices and with much needed ideas. Give a woman a room and the next thing you know she’s taken the world.…Toni Morrison, whom I publish, said so beautifully in her 1993 Nobel lecture, Tell us what it is to be a woman…what moves at the margin. What it is to have no home in this place. To be set adrift from the one you knew. What it is to live at the edge of towns that cannot bear your company. Our mongrel nation understands the margins.

p.ref: In 1999, I published one of the early world-changing Canadian non-fiction Big Ideas books, Naomi Klein’s No Logo, which has sold in about forty-five languages. A brilliant, rabble-rousing work for a whole generation, it tore the branding consumer culture to shreds and took on the misconceptions of globalization; many of those who took to the streets in protest in Montreal and in Seattle, who camped outside the walls of Davos in Switzerland for the economic summits, the workers who demonstrated in the streets of Manila and Buenos Aires, carried that book as their bible. I was Naomi’s editor; she was just twenty-six at the time, and I know many people initially told her that she should move on, that she was inadequately trained to the task, that she would be ignored by the experts in the field, that the world would not pay attention to her. She followed No Logo with The Shock Doctrine, also a #1 bestseller in many countries, and hailed by the Nobel-winning economist Joseph Stiglitz as a book to be read by all economists who cared about the word they live in. Virginia Woolf is an odd great-grandmother for Naomi Klein, but she would not have disapproved of her desire to influence and shed light on reality, or, as Naomi said in her own succinct way in an online video on Big Think, When you read strong analysis, clear analysis, it makes you feel better equipped; it’s sort of ammo. As an opinion writer, as a columnist, that’s my goal: helping people get more of those clicks of understanding. Other books followed in my own working life—Stephanie Nolen’s groundbreaking book on AIDS, 28; and Irshad Manji’s The Trouble with Islam Today. As a young woman in her early twenties living in Toronto, Manji decided to speak up for the generous moderate Islam that she passionately advocates for in her book. A brave move—she lives under a fatwa—but her book is read and debated around the world, forging a path for tolerance.

Another woman who has moved out of the margins and pulled down a fatwa on her head in so doing is Ayaan Hirsi Ali. She wrote in her bestselling Infidel of her flight from a forced marriage as a child to a much older man (living in Canada)—and in Nomad, her inspiring 2010 book, she tells the story of her continuing journey to escape and find a new life. She is articulate, astonishing, beautiful, and unbelievably courageous. She has taken on the cause of eradicating female genital mutilation and fully knows she is writing inflammatory work, but tells me, when I worry for her safety, that to inspire change on any level, she must be as staunch as possible. She sees the plight of women and radical Islam as the most urgent problem on the planet, one that affects us all: she is not a feminist, she says, but a human being. There is, she says, a horrific silence from the mainstream. And note there is no unified political perspective or women’s perspective. Ayaan and Naomi would not be political bedfellows, but they are nevertheless both critical important voices in the world debate.

In many parts of the world, however, a room of one’s own is still a secret room. Azar Nafisi, in her bestselling book Reading Lolita in Tehran, about teaching Western literature in secret to her students, wrote: For nearly two years, almost every Thursday morning, rain or shine, they came to my house, and almost every time, I could not get over the shock of seeing them shed their mandatory veils and robes and burst into color. When my students came into that room, they took off more than their scarves and robes. Gradually, each one gained an outline and a shape, becoming her own inimitable self. Our world, in that small room, with its window framing my beloved Elburz Mountains became our sanctuary, our self-contained universe, mocking the reality of black-scarved, timid faces in the city that sprawled below. (5–6)

ref.ref: I want to end by telling you of a personal story of a fight for the rights of one woman, which brings us into the powerful world of electronic communication. In July 2010, Heather Reisman, who runs the Indigo book chain, called me to say she had that morning read a plea from a twenty-two-year-old boy in Iran, begging the world to intervene to save his mother’s life, alleging her innocence. Forty-two-year-old Sakineh Ashtiani was in Tabriz prison and due to be executed that weekend by stoning for so-called adultery—buried up to her neck and then stoned to death by a gathered crowd. That day we created a small committee—women and men—Azar Nafisi, Irshad Manji, Shirin Ebadi, the Nobel-winning Iranian lawyer whose book I had published, lawyers, and advisors—and started emailing. Within twenty-four hours, we had a website up with a petition to the regime. Within five days, we had sent off three hundred thousand signed petitions. Sakineh’s stoning was delayed, as the regime regrouped. Eight hard-working people managed to bring this barbaric, cruel practice to the news of every country—all through the new digital world of social media. A publishing friend in Brazil created a brilliant social media campaign he called Lula Liga: Lula call. President Lula, being in the middle of an election and bombarded by thousands of Brazilians calling on him to call President Ahmadinejad in Iran, reluctantly called and offered Sakineh and her family a home in Brazil. Ahmadinejad told him, in so many words, that he was a fool. Brazil responded by imposing sanctions on Iran. Sarkozy in France became involved, and when the Iranian regime called his wife a prostitute, world politics changed yet again. Sakineh was not stoned to death and is still alive. Yet she is still in prison. Many more women wait on death row to be stoned, and the world continues to appeal to the regime for compassion and for the abolishment of stoning and of adultery as a capital punishment.

p.ref: Transformative change is part of our legacy and our lifeblood in Canada. Canadian writers have moved from the colonial margins to the very centre of world literature; and women writers have taken their place in that centre, provoking change, as much as witnessing it. Our goal is to keep moving, to continue to address injustice, the meaning of life, and to celebrate its joys and sorrows. Whether that is pushing against racial, sexual, or political boundaries, whether it’s Naomi Klein raising her voice in the public forum or a group of women learning together in secret in a room of their own in Tehran, we move forward, we grow together through our need to participate in our own reality. As Canadians we know, just as writers in all fields know, that we must never stop struggling against those who would give us no for an answer or shut a door in our face, never stop struggling against the barriers that hinder our ability to dream aloud, to write, or paint, or make music, to challenge the darkness, and dream a humane society into being. And if we do it well, here in Canada, the world will listen.

head.q: To Get In Behind the Curtain

div.byline: Miriam Green Ellis’s Travels and Tales
div.q: A woman may be the most wonderful designer in the world and still not be able to write how she does it. She may be the most wonderful maker of apple pies in the world, but she cannot tell how she does it—a few apples and a little sugar. So I think that the training of a reporter is primarily important; a good power of observation may come next, and brains should be used if available.
div.p: —Miriam Green Ellis, Special Fields, Triennial of the Canadian Women’s Press Club, Calgary, 1932
div.q: I resent the smug manner with which some pseudo-farmers and politicians refer to themselves as dirt farmers. To me those are fighting words. That is supposed to be a slam at someone, but what other kind of farmer is there than the one who works in the dirt? The better use he makes of that dirt, the better farmer he is, the more he has to contribute to the food supplies of his neighbours in town.
div.p: —Miriam Green Ellis, Aggie Stag Banquet, University of Manitoba, 1948

p.ref: On the occasion of the retirement of Miriam Green Ellis at the age of seventy-three as western editor of the Montreal paper the Family Herald and Weekly Star for over twenty-five years, the past president of the Canadian Women’s Press Club (CWPC), Kennethe Haig, hailed her colleague as that incredible Canadian (Cram 7). The celebration took place in Winnipeg in early January 1953. Ellis had signed on formally in 1913 as a member of the CWPC, which, making history as well as news, claims the longest continuous existence of any professional women journalists’ organization in the world (Jackel 53), and renewed affiliation as a continuous, active member (Triennial Report of CWPC) until her death in 1964. But she was much more than an affiliate. Ellis served as president of the Edmonton branch of the CWPC in 1919 and, in many subsequent roles for this branch, arranged the first CWPC regional conference in Calgary in 1920, served several terms as vice-president of the regional CWPC, and wrote a characteristically informal history of the CWPC, Pathfinders, delivered as a talk at the biennial in Edmonton in 1956. She was more than an organizer, too. The vast scope of her published and always personally coloured articles covers topics ranging from stock prices, farm fairs, prize-winning wheat, and farmer-entrepreneurs to learning to drive and change a tire in 1916, camping in the Rockies, and visiting the fledgling Banff School of Fine Arts. In addition to crisscrossing Western Canada countless times on her aggie beat, she extended her field to observe Atlantic Canada, reporting on ox-pulls, haymaking, cod and lobster fisheries, and coal mining in Nova Scotia, Cape Breton, and Prince Edward Island, and ventured as far as Honolulu where, being welcomed as the Dean of Canada’s newspaper women (Dean, n. pag.), she sent back copy about Hawaiian cattle ranches, sugar cane harvests, floral industries, and the active Kilauea and Mauna Loa volcanoes on the Big Island.

ref.ref: The largely unmined Ellis Collection, willed to the University of Alberta, contains holograph manuscripts and typewritten manuscripts, two short stories, and the typescript of her journey from Edmonton to Aklavik, Northwest Territories, in June and July 1922, entitled Down North,

along with 237 photographs, at least half of which were transferred through the technology of the day to coloured glass slides to illustrate her Journey to the Land of the Midnight Sun lectures across Canada and the United States. Watercolour artists with fine sable brushes welcomed the calotype technique of painting and glazing paper-based photographs, which allowed them precision in detailing facial and costume features (Henisch, Heinz, and Henisch 53). The coloured slides of Ellis’s magic lantern shows captured real life (Humphries 24) in novel ways.

p.ref: Photographs of and keepsakes from friends (Emily Murphy, Nellie McClung, Gertrude Peggy Balmer, E. Cora Hind, and Violet McNaughton among them) add to the trove’s enlivened sense of the West in the first decades of the twentieth century, of a woman making her mark in a male-dominated field, and of the sustaining bonds among press women.

Poring over the contents of the Ellis Collection, an archive made from selected and consciously chosen documentation from the past and also from the mad fragments that no one intended to preserve and just ended up there (Steedman 68), has taught me many things about Miriam. A woman of daring, wry humour, and tough-mindedness, a diarist, a writer of non-fiction and fiction, a promoter of rural life and agricultural communities, and a champion of press women who exemplifies their motto, Every Stroke Upward (Rex 1), this incredible Canadian is also a person of mystery.

Despite the accessible tenor and subjects of her widely circulated publications and their marks of a strong, determined personality, Ellis herself as an individual subject is less and less fathomable. Elusiveness is actually not the problem; it is, rather, the thread that connects the work of over four decades of the woman who wanted to get in behind the curtain (Down North, 64), but chose not to lift the veil on her own life.

The more I considered the feasibility of resurrecting a figure about whom so little has been written (with the exception of excerpts from the 1922 diary introduced by Lisa LaFramboise, and slight mention in studies by Grant MacEwan, Kay Rex, and Marjory Lang) and about whom so many unanswered, or unanswerable, or impertinent questions persist, the less comfortable I became with the self-styled role as revisionist or un-coverer. On the contrary, it seems important to establish a place in literary studies for the press woman not as a mere hack, bereft of the trimmings of non-linear narration, extended metaphorical allusions, or récherché diction.

After a necessarily brief biographical sketch, I plan to get in behind the curtain of Ellis’s once widely circulated copy to concentrate on the hidden art of her unpublished work: Down North and the two short stories, Alone and A War Bride’s Return.
p.note: For an annotated, illustrated edition of Down North and a selection of Miriam Green Ellis’s fiction and journalism, see Travels and Tales of Miriam Green Ellis: Pioneer Journalist of the Canadian West, ed. Patricia Demers (U of Alberta P, 2013). For photographs, coloured glass slides, and items from the Miriam Green Ellis Collection, visit the web exhibit hosted by the Bruce Peel Special Collections Library: www.library.ualberta.ca/specialcollections.

div.p: Born in Richville, New York, of Canadian parents, who returned to Canada and the paternal farmstead near Athens, Ontario, where this only child went to school, she later attended Bishop Strachan School in Toronto and graduated from the Toronto Conservatory of Music with an ATCM (Associate of the Toronto Conservatory of Music) diploma. The Green family’s move to Edmonton in 1904 was followed by her marriage to George Ellis in All Saints Anglican in 1905. Inspector of Schools for Edmonton from 1906 to 1908, Ellis, a graduate of Athens High School and Queen’s University, attended the inaugural University of Alberta convocation in the Strathcona Oddfellows’ Hall in 1908, seated next to the minister of education, A.C. Rutherford. George Ellis resigned his position in 1909 to pursue graduate work with Miriam’s accompaniment, likely in Chicago. The next appearance of Miriam in any archive is her role in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, where, in 1912, she started and managed the girls’ hockey team of the Prince Albert Collegiate Institute, where George was principal. Ladies’ hockey was very popular in Saskatchewan, with Regina boasting its first ladies’ team as early as 1896, and the Prince Albert Tumblers in action in 1907 (Zeman 252–53). Based on reports in the Prince Albert Daily Herald, Miriam acquired a considerable reputation as a curler. She also began writing for this local paper, though the lack of bylines makes her contributions impossible to trace. She reported on the 1915 Regina meeting of the Women Grain Growers, a splendid organization, which stands above all for cooperation (Women Grain Growers, 11), and their mounting campaign for suffrage for the Toronto-based monthly Woman’s Century. For a short time, she was a staffer at the Regina Leader-Post before joining Frank Oliver’s Edmonton Bulletin, reporting on the legislature, various churches, sports, and agriculture. Miriam’s year as Edmonton president of the CWPC was characterized not only by her preparation of Bohemian refreshments for the soiree[s] (John D. Hunt is Honor Guest, n. pag.) but also by an engagement with a larger community; speakers and invited guests for the year included Father Drummond of the Jesuit College, Winnipeg press woman E. Cora Hind, whom Ellis introduced as being called on to do the work of three men for half a man’s salary (Press Club Entertains, n. pag), Dean of Agriculture E.A. Howes, and Acting President William Kerr of the University of Alberta, aesthetic dancer Ruth St. Denis, Premier Charles Stewart, and mountaineer Mary Jobe.

Newspaper articles, correspondence, and typescripts provide some details, but curious gaps or omissions, her distinctive leitmotif, remain. George enlisted as a major in the Canadian Expeditionary Force in 1915. According to his personnel record, he was dismissed in 1916 for misconduct (Veterans Affairs, RG 150 Accession 1992–93 / 166), an unexplained term, and returned to Eastern Ontario, to the Leeds County area of his birth. From 1922 until 1938, he taught at Lisgar Collegiate Institute in Ottawa, while Miriam lived in Edmonton and, later, Winnipeg. No record of a divorce exists. Reporting on all sorts of conventions and often appearing in breeks, Miriam always signed her writing Miriam Green Ellis, yet no obituary or memoir of Miriam mentions George or the childless marriage. In speaking to the University Women’s Club in Saskatoon in 1945, she borrowed a description from her favorite book, Winnie the Pooh to compare herself to Rabbit’s relations: I am the last little relation following the procession and sometimes getting lost (Watching Other People Farm, 18–19). Whether this is an ironic retrospective or tongue-in-cheek candour from a recognizable though discreet personality, who never seemed lost, is arguable.

A reading of her typescript Down North along with the 249 small pages (3.5" x 6") of typed daily diary entries, index of names, and demographic information relating to her 1922 journey to Aklavik testifies to Ellis’s purposiveness, curiosity, and determination. Having failed to convince editor Frank Oliver of readers’ interest in reports of such a trip, with typical boldness she granted herself a leave of absence. She travelled by train to Waterways, the terminus of the Alberta and Great Waterways Railway, south of Fort McMurray, and then by river steamer down the Athabasca, crossing the rapids by car at Smith Portage, and proceeding by steamer north on the Mackenzie to Aklavik.

p.ref: Down North is full of candid portraits, textual and photographic, of fellow passengers. With a hint of disbelief she describes Gladys Patterson, a girl from Yorkshire, England, going down to marry a chap at Norman whom she has not seen…since the war and of course has not heard from him since last Fall some time, but she does not seem to have any doubts in the matter (4). At the Edmonton train station she meets Bishop Grouard, the Oblate missionary who oversaw the immense vicariate of Athabasca-Mackenzie and brought the first printing press to Athabasca country. He has been in the north for half a century and knows every white man and Indian right down to the Arctic.…He is well over eighty now but still carries on as active head of his big diocese (4–5). Although not photographed, botany professor Roland Holroyd from Pennsylvania State University is initially an instructive source—it will be interesting getting some first hand information about the plants and flowers (4)—but soon proves a disappointment when he refuses or is unable to identify any vegetation. Her frustration with this reclusive passenger is evident when she comments on his attempted moustache, a rather anaemic affair. After weeks of sober living he has suddenly given way to smoking cigarettes, but he does it very genteelly, using a six-inch amber holder. We have warned him to be careful, as dear knows what would grow there if the wooly down were burned off. Poplar comes where spruce has been burned off, we tell him; maybe feather follows down. (35)

div.p: Wishing that our fat friend of the Botany department would part with some of the secrets of his profession (44), she resorts to William McCalla’s Wild Flowers of Western Canada as a more reliable guide. Her sympathies are engaged for the young Inuit prisoner Alikomiak at Fort McPherson, to be tried and eventually hanged for four murders: The lad looks about sixteen but they say he is nineteen. He says that he did not mean to kill Doak but just shot to wound him and force retaliation (43). On the return journey up south on the Mackenzie, an Inuit woman, Laura, who was being forced to Edmonton to appear before Justice Murphy and possibly confined as insane for having beat her husband, claims Ellis’s sympathy. I suggested that perhaps the husband needed beating up (57), she observes. She presents this portrait of Laura: All day she sits or stands out on the side deck, rolling cigarettes and smoking. When she gets tired standing, she sits flat down on the floor with her legs straight out in front like a baby. That would be a new one to add to the daily dozen and warranted to strengthen the back (59). Ellis is happy to report parenthetically that Laura was found mentally all right and sent back, her worst fault seeming to be that she was an inveterate smoker and also drank when the opportunity offered (57). She encounters and relates tales of survival, like the Pittsburgh native who suffered gangrene, eventually amputated his own toes with a jackknife, and survived alone for over four months with only twenty-five pounds of flour that he mixed with snow, and who now does not want to leave the North.

p.ref: Thanks to Ellis’s keen eye, Down North is equally adept at documenting topographical conditions. Her text has prescient observations on the tar sands, regular mountains of asphalt (7), used at the time for superior road surfaces, as one day going to mean millions of dollars to the country; despite the opinion of the cracker-box orators (61) on board, squelching one’s enthusiasms that it was just some fool scratching round in the dirt (7), Ellis maintains her visions of another Klondyke (8). She documents Native women’s importance in preparing hides, befriends Native families, notes features of dress, childcare, and diet, and records Native delight in taking pictures of the white visitors. As well as entering mission schools and churches and investigating operating room procedures, such as the one at Fort Simpson, she relays considerable exuberance and vulnerability—in piloting the boat for thirty miles beyond Fort Chipewyan and taking a daily swim in the Mackenzie, admitting to anxiety about mounting her first horse—I cannot understand why they put the stirrups up so high (65)—and, at Salt Springs, a thirty-seven-mile journey inland, revealing the perils of a tenderfoot who deals with blistered feet.

A strong-willed personality suffuses every page of Down North. From the outset Ellis chafes at her editor’s apparent lack of interest in her proposed trip to the North Pole, as this episode in early spring illustrates. One day I sat in the Premier’s office trying to get a scoop on the government policy in connection with the administration of the liquor laws, when I noticed on his desk a pamphlet from a transportation company, on which were the words To the land of the midnight sun. From where I sat in that big blue room, I could see the North Saskatchewan River, just then throwing off its winter bondage and shoving the great cakes of ice ignominiously on the shore to rot. The trees were showing life and the grass along the banks was getting green. It was the time the woods sent out their loudest call, and I lost all interest in the burning question of liquor laws. (2) She also strikes a blow for women in breeks, but not without a shamefaced admission. Having put on [her] knickers and big boots…with a defiant air, Ellis is anxious to see what was behind that screen of trees…to penetrate the leafy foliage (7–8). For one time only she concedes to the captain’s directive that he could not think of allowing me to leave the boat, but quickly vows that it won’t happen again (10). Her oath packs conviction: That man is about half as big as I am and I should just have taken him by the collar and thrown him overboard (8). Her trips ashore have a less pugnacious tone, showing an observant naturalist at work. The discovery of wild orchids, the most exquisite things I ever saw, remind her of fairies’ graves (17). Blue-eyed grass, lupines, tea berries, wild strawberries, and the omnipresent pink, rose, and purple drooping blossoms of the Heydesarum mackenzii merit detailed description. So do the never-ending sunsets, liquid light lying on the water (37), a bright rich amber, shading to yellow gold (47). The prospect of a return journey along narrower and shallower rivers, unlike the majesty of the Mackenzie, occasions sadness: it was like the slow unfurling of a great banner, and now we are rolling it up again till it will be just an uninteresting stick (58). Sick of being rushed (64), Ellis rejoices in the reprieve of having missed the boat, meaning that their return is delayed for a few days.

div.p: Down North, 1922, likely composed in the fall of that year and mined successively thereafter for newspaper articles, is a significant and singular contribution to women’s travel accounts dealing with Western Canada and the Arctic. Its distinctive immediacy emerging from Ellis’s journalism experience, Down North also stands apart from the published records of earlier and contemporary women recreational adventurers or professional travel writers, who were supported by family wealth, industrial sponsors or employed, attending husbands. The personal voice, occasional humiliation, and the encounter with a wide social spectrum separate Ellis’s work from the amateur Victorian travelogues of the wives of serving or future Canadian governors-general detailing their cross-country visits with the elite of the Dominion: the Marchioness of Dufferin and Ava’s My Canadian Journal, 1872–8: Extracts from My Letters Home (1891) and the Marchioness of Aberdeen’s Through Canada with a Kodak (1893). Though incomplete (or at least un-concluded), Ellis’s account is fuller than the report of the American Elizabeth Taylor, a self-taught botanist and collector for museums, who travelled down the Mackenzie in 1892 with the permission of the governor of the Hudson’s Bay Company, publishing brief essays two and five years later in Outing and Travel. In addition to Taylor’s timidity about Indian fellow travellers, a rough wild set, about whom she registers feeling a little troubled in having [her] tent pitched so near (Taylor, Lady’s Journey 51), she fulfils the requirement of the travelling lady in recommending such useful articles as a checked skirt, blouse, felt hat, silk handkerchiefs, moosehide gloves, and black cashmere stockings (Taylor, Articles 60). Ellis’s individual experience and first-person voice distinguish her work from the stereotypes and condescending tone of the essays and stories of Quebec-born Harriet Campbell, Lady Jephson’s A Canadian Scrap-Book (1897), and the fictional first-person narration of Bess Le Ford in Norfolk-born Frances Herring’s portraits of the British Columbia Interior, Canadian Camp Life (1900). Later records of travel show considerably less travail than Ellis’s account. Jean Walker Godsell’s description of her 1920 honeymoon trip north as a Hudson’s Bay Company factor’s wife, in I was No Lady (1959), sketches God’s Wide Open Spaces where men were men and where white women were placed on pedestals since they were few in number and far between (Godsell 2).Clara (Rogers) Vyvyan’s 1926 journey by steamer, motor boat, and canoe to Alaska published thirty-five years later as Arctic Adventure (1961), a carefully planned and guided trip, reflects the aspirations of a well-to-do, middle-aged Englishwoman and her female artist-companion as they read Shakespeare to one another en route.

The journey most comparable to Ellis’s is Agnes Deans Cameron’s arrival at Fort Rae in 1908, recounted in The New North (1909), a text that Ellis’s informal history of the CWPC reveals she knew. That book came back at me like a boomerang, Ellis revealed to her Edmonton audience : When I went down the Mackenzie in 1922, the natives clammed up on me when I said I wanted to write about them. Seems Cameron had borrowed precious photographs and failed to return them, as promised (Ellis, Pathfinders 8).

Aside from competing claims about being the first to visit Salt Springs, the biggest differences between these two accounts are their scope and tone. With each of its twenty-four chapters headed by a literary or biblical epigraph, The New North is a precisely worded, photo-illustrated narrative of close to four hundred pages, recounting the journey of Cameron and her niece, an accommodating typist, from Chicago to the North, via stagecoach, scow, steamer, and paddle-wheeler, with a return terminus in Winnipeg. The text directly links a photographic first to a technology of textual representation—the typewriter (Roy, Maps 212). Although not all the photographs were taken by Cameron or Miss Jessie Cameron Brown, it is quite possible, as Wendy Roy suggests, that Underwood either donated the typewriter or helped to fund the trip and was rewarded by having its corporate name prominently displayed (Primacy, 73). Cameron (1863–1912) was not officially a press woman; rather, as a teacher for twenty-five years and the first woman high school principal in Victoria, she had run afoul of the school board trustees and been dismissed. Journalism in Chicago and the trip north, along with its resultant lectures in Britain and the United States promoting immigration, provided her livelihood before her untimely death. In the opinion of Anglican missionary Archdeacon Charles Whittaker, The New North was an intricate compound of fact and fiction (MacLaren and LaFramboise xxix).

p.ref: Instead of splitting hairs over truth claims separating the journalist and the educator, a more revealing yet delicate comparison involves the tone of both accounts. Acutely conscious of her role as instructive authority over curious observer, Cameron is quick to impart anthropological lessons. Among Mackenzie tribes no Yellow-Knife, Dog-Rib, or Slavi starved while another had meat, no thievish hand despoiled the cache of another. A man’s word was his bond, and a promise was kept to the death. Not all the real things of life are taught to the Cree by the Christian. Courage is better than culture, playing the game of more importance than the surface niceties of civilisation, to be a man now of more moment than to hope to be an angel hereafter. (Cameron 199) In contrast to Ellis’s awestruck directness, the vision of sunset at the Ramparts, the entrance to Fort Good Hope, provokes a Romantic effusion from Cameron, in which duelling emphases on aloneness and impressive pronouncement frame the scene. Awed and uplifted, our one wish is to be alone; the vision that is ours for one hour of this Arctic night repays the whole summer’s travel. The setting of the picture is that ineffable light, clear yet mellow, which without dawn and without twilight rises from the flowing river to starless heavens, and envelopes the earth as with a garment—the light that never was on sea or land. We could not have chosen a more impressive hour in which to pass the portal into the Arctic World. (Cameron 206) While the differences in length and aim between a typescript and a published volume might challenge the feasibility of this comparison, what emerges as significant are the palpable contrasts in tone between the teacher at ease in lecturing and the journalist pursuing human interest.
Ellis’s two short stories, another unique offshoot of the journey north, have no parallel in the subsequent work of other women travellers.

These narratives probe Native–white relations with a remarkable willingness to see and articulate both sides of the emotionally fraught issues of identity and belonging. A tautly narrated exploration of dissociation, Alone follows the thoughts and escape routes of a hunted man wanted for murder ten years earlier. Moving from the Crowsnest Pass to the Nahanni River in the Northwest Territories, it highlights the man’s terror of uncertainty, his realization of betrayal from so many others, and the surprising sympathy his death evokes in the Native girl he has abducted.

For Carson, the man on the run, fear is an embodied presence: But fear, ingrowing and unceasing, gripped him in its coils, like the devilfish, its victim. As time passed, its clutches grew stronger and stronger, till he wondered how much longer he could withstand the vicious monster (1).

The domestic and emotional details Ellis introduces to her portrait of this terrifying grip create a poignant sense of estrangement and alienation. With the passage of years, Carson’s promise to his childhood sweetheart in England, Have your sheets and tablecloths all hemmed, and I will be back for you in two years (3) and his plans for a home with no rent to pay to greedy landlords (4) fade to impossibility. As he risks journeys to Vancouver and San Francisco, his attempt to track down the double-crossing prospector, his supposed partner, shows the gullibility to which loneliness has reduced him and confirms that his stake and money are both lost. The shocking act of abduction testifies to Carson’s desperation and muddled thinking: he must have her for his own; if her people pursued, as they doubtless would, he would fly with her. He had eluded the police for ten years; he could elude them too (19–20). However, Alone is not a rape narrative, nor does it illustrate what we would today call the Stockholm Syndrome. Ellis succeeds in complicating both victim and perpetrator. Though terrified and unable to communicate, the girl realizes that this man did not mean to hurt her (21). As the narrator explains for her, an Indian maiden could read the tenderness in his eyes, yearning blue eyes so unlike those of the indifferent men of her tribe (20). Despite escaping to the far side of the river, the girl screams, runs, and wades into the river to try to stop the raft on which Carson, who has abandoned hope, is careening toward the rapids. Managing to pull his lifeless body to shore, she cradles his head and lies down by his side. In death, he was not alone (24).

div.p: A War Bride’s Return may have been prompted by Ellis’s silent question about Gladys Patterson’s blithe happiness en route to marry her long-separated fiancé. In her story, the sheltered English war bride arrives in Edmonton to start a romantic new life of genteel farming, only to be shocked and horrified by the realization that her beloved Canadian husband, whom she nursed back to health in France, is Native. The bride’s immediate revulsion, her change from love to hate, and refusal to listen to any explanation are strong indictments of prevailing prejudices. The contrast between Rose’s professed love and readily upturned lips (Chap. 2, 1) at the Edmonton train station when the couple is reunited at last and her silent petulance hours later casts doubt on all her declarations. The subtlety of the narrative inheres both in the warm relationship between the husband and his mother, who has educated him and kept the subsistence farm going in his absence, and the delayed disclosure about true parentage. Although Ellis works hard to air the views and desires of both sides of this doomed partnership, she spends most time dissecting John’s interior dilemma and ambivalence, torn between his duty to his mother and his love for his wife (Chap. 2, 5). Rose constantly questions, extracting protestations of fidelity and explanations about a beloved collie: You do love me, do you not? and Was there another girl, John? (Chap. 1, 4), Who is Flossie? You talked of her all night in your sleep (Chap. 2, 3). Afraid that Rose would not understand (Chap. 2, 5) and shiver[ing] in dread at the outcome (Chap. 2, 1), John makes the effort to see matters from Rose’s uninformed and judgemental perspective: He was not ashamed of it, but how would it seem to an English girl who knew nothing of Indians except such as she had read in Cooper’s novels. But, he defended himself again, he could not tell her of himself without seeming to cast a slur on that mother, who had done so much for him (Chap. 2, 1).

p.ref: The unnamed Mother reads Rose’s language perfectly: No, she will never understand. I saw the look of horror in her eyes when she saw me (Chap. 3, 2). For her part, Rose recoils in revulsion: Don’t touch me. I hate you…I wish I might have died before this happened (Chap. 3, 5).

Possibly echoing the situation of separation in her own life, Ellis’s principals do not get together, yet the current of sexual tension carries through to the final line. The former bride, who is using her stenographer’s salary to start her own chicken business in Edmonton, decides to invest in hens but she would not get a cock till later on (Chap. 5, 9).

div.p: Why would work so vivid in its emotional insights, so attuned to the cadences of speech, and so knowledgeably anchored in an Albertan or Arctic setting remain unpublished? What shines through in all Ellis’s work are the candour, admiration for resourcefulness, and fighting spirit of the writer. She was not an observer who kept her distance, but an understanding listener eager to support the underdog. Ironically, despite Ellis’s wide recognition—a farmer at Fort Smith recognized her from the Edmonton Exhibition and a Californian student at the Banff School remembered her from the International Stock Show at Chicago thirteen years earlier—she remains a figure of considerable mystery. The typescript of her journey to Aklavik provided material for over forty newspaper articles. Fiction may have been a more tentative undertaking for Ellis; she may have been stung by rejection or chosen not to consult or prevail on her friend Nellie McClung for a literary contact.

This temperamental fighting spirit, however, does not align her with the contemporary fictional journalist Aleta Dey, the eponymous heroine of Francis Marion Beynon’s largely autobiographical 1919 novel. Pacifist and suffragist, Dey suffers and dies for her principles. She constantly accuses herself of weakness: Why did I find myself apologetic when I did not agree with the majority? When I was given a mind that questioned everything, why was I not given a spirit that feared nothing? (Beynon 66). Combining both a questioning attitude and a fearless brio, Ellis never believed that the wings of [her] soul had been clipped in [her] infancy (Beynon 66).

While it may seem easy to categorize Ellis as fleeing from the perceived boredom of a music teaching career and a failed marriage into the sorority of press women, I think it is important to see beyond these stereotypes. Boldly claiming and ultimately owning the male turf of the aggie beat, resorting to no coy nicknames, not isolating herself as a Lone Scribe (Lang 22) but rather seizing the advantage of the Aklavik trip to negotiate a new position, Ellis experienced the enabling power of a female constituency and exercised genuine resourcefulness in the sometimes hostile terrain of the newspaper world. Yet she recognized with some regret, in the years following the Second World War, that the need for the solidarity of a women-only association was waning. In many ways she is a liminal figure, valuing the pluck of CWPC pioneers and exulting in her own mobility. Her conversational style, so distinct from the didactic literariness of Agnes Deans Cameron, nevertheless blends clarity and opacity, as this public personality protects the secrets of a private individual.

p.ref: Depuis le succès public et critique de son roman Le ciel de Bay City Le roman a remporté au Québec le Grand Prix des Libraires, le Prix du livre de Montréal et le Prix littéraire des collégiens.en 2008 (réédité à Paris en 2009 chez Sabine Wespieser), Catherine Mavrikakis est devenue une figure de proue de la relève littéraire québécoiseJe fais par là référence à une nouvelle génération de maisons d’édition créées à Montréal depuis les années 2000 : Héliotrope, Les Allusifs, Le Quartanier, Le Marchand de Feuilles, Alto, Le Lézard amoureux, qui s’illustrent, outre par la nouvelle génération d’auteurs qu’elles publient, par un soin particulier apporté au graphisme. Un article du journal étudiant Quartier libre a ainsi titré Nouvelle vague dans l’édition québécoise (Mercier, 2009).. Son œuvre critique est aussi saluée, notamment avec l’essai Condamner à mort. Les meurtres et la loi à l’écran, récipiendaire du prix de l’Académie des Lettres du Québec Victor-Barbeau en 2006.

ref.ref: Cependant, au croisement de l’œuvre littéraire et de pensée, ne séparant pas l’une de l’autre, son écriture s’est mise à essaimer autrement avec la création par sa maison d’édition montréalaise, Héliotrope, du blogue catherinemavrikakis.com. Les textes qui y sont parus ont été republiés à l’automne 2010 sous la forme d’un livre désigné comme e-carnet et intitulé L’éternité en accéléré. Enfin, Catherine Mavrikakis a créé pour le site Internet Radio-Spiralehttp://radiospirale.org/emission/revez-pour-moi., émanation du magazine culturel montréalais Spirale, une émission de radio alternative, Rêvez pour moi, produite sous forme de conversations dans lesquelles elle demande à ses invités de lui raconter leurs rêves.

p.ref: Je veux faire l’hypothèse que, par ces nouveaux formats, Catherine Mavrikakis ne s’efforce pas seulement, techniquement, d’emprunter les moyens de son temps, mais propose de façon plus intéressante une réflexion sur le contemporain comme co-énonciation, co-responsabilité et méditation sur le temps d’une vie. J’appuierai mon investigation sur trois textes publiés sur le blogue. Le premier, intitulé Nos rêves les plus fous, critique la propagande populiste de John McCain, construite sur la figure de Joe the plumber et l’idée d’un rêve partagé par tous. Le second, Back-slide with Michael, met en jeu une défense de Michael Jackson en tant qu’ex-icône culturelle tombée dans une disgrâce que même sa mort n’a pu racheter. Enfin, je me pencherai sur la réflexion que propose Mavrikakis de la notion de vie, réflexion qui court en filigrane tout au long de ces chroniques et s’incarne dans un texte en particulier, nommé Moments fragiles.

Commentant la chronique de Marguerite Duras publiée dans le quotidien français Libération au cours de L’'été 80, Arnaud Bernadet écrit que l’auteure y opère une subjectivation de l’actualité (28). Autrement dit, le caractère contingent du temps chronique, aveugle et indifférent, s’y voit tout à coup personnalisé par l’écriture — non seulement parce que l’auteure choisit tel ou tel événement dans la masse d’informations que lui offre le monde, mais aussi parce que, l’écrivant, elle en fait la matière de sa propre vie. Or la force de ce que Marguerite Duras a ainsi appelé le seul journal de [s]a vie (La vie matérielle 11) vient de ce que dans ces papiers d’un jourC’est le sous-titre de l’un de ses recueils de textes écrits pour les journaux, Outside 1. Papiers d’un jour.se nouaient la dimension de l’événement politique à la fois éloigné et poignant qui se déroulait pendant qu’elle écrivait — exemplairement les grèves des ouvriers de Gdansk — et celle quotidienne du spectacle de la plage, où chaque jour s’intensifiait la tendresse d’une monitrice de colonie de vacances pour l’un des jeunes enfants.

Sur le blogue de Catherine Mavrikakis, catherinemavrikakis.com, il n’en va pas autrement. Un événement auquel nous assistons tous, une actualité à la fois insignifiante dans sa banalité et potentiellement grave dans son contenu politique, mais dont nous sentons que le jour va l’emmener, les semaines l’oublier, tout à coup est retenu par l’auteure pour la résonance qu’il vient produire en elle, écho d’autres événements, ou ranimant en elle des souvenirs. Ainsi, dans un texte intitulé Nos rêves les plus fous, Mavrikakis écrit :
We all have the same dream as Joe the plumber. C’est ce que le candidat républicain à la présidence des États-Unis martèle dans ses grands rassemblements. Nous aurions tous le même rêve, le rêve américain, de Joe, de celui qui ne veut pas payer d’impôts, qui rêve que sa business fonctionne bien et que sa vie s’écoule sans heurt dans sa banlieue blanche. Nous aurions tous ce rêve-là.
Moi, je le confesse, je ne rêve pas de cela. (Nos rêves 135) Contre le rêve de Joe the plumber, contre le rêve de Goebbels aussi que, dans un élargissement politique de la réflexion, elle rappelle ensuite, Mavrikakis choisit en finale le rêve de Martin Luther King. Mais ce qu’elle montre surtout, c’est que le rêve ne saurait être rêvé collectivement. C’est seulement ensuite, par le choix de chaque singularité d’épouser la singularité d’un autre, qu’il peut se faire espace commun. Car ce qui réside dans le rêve est, fondamentalement, idiosyncrasique, et c’est ce qui fait du rêve justement le dernier espace de résistance contre les idéologies — du moins faudrait-il le préserver comme tel. Plaqué sur d’autres contre leur gré ou bien à leur insu, le rêve n’est plus que propagande : il se fait rêve de dominer jusqu’aux rêves des autres, alors qu’on ne peut rêver que par soi-même.

ref.ref: Le travail du blogue est de cette dimension : se faire le support évanescent — mais qui dure — des pensées d’un instant ou d’un jour, offertes en partage pour que leur singularité rencontre une autre singularité, non pas imposées, mais circulant avec une liberté plus grande que par le livre, que par les journaux. À l’instar du rêve rêvé par chacun, dont on ne devrait jamais oublier ce qu’il a d’intime, la page Internet d’écrivain se présente comme le lieu ultime de résistance au grand ordre imposé du monde, et notamment à l’ordre imposé par l’actualité — qui n’est jamais choisie que par quelques-uns.

Ainsi l’auteure remarque-t-elle, au sujet d’une perte de foi dans la notion d’ esprit collectif générationnel que lui inspire la mort de Michael Jackson, qu’elle ne fonde plus [s]es propos sur le mensonge d’une communauté qui a une même époque à consommer (Back-slide 25). Pourtant, vieillir et écrire au jour le jour, c’est reconnaître qu’il est arrivé un temps de ma vie où il m’est devenu évident que je ne suis pas beaucoup plus que l’époque qui m’a formée: Je vois combien je suis réduite au moment où j’ai pensé que tout était possible (28), ces années 80 où l’auteure avait vingt ans. Il est alors difficile d’assumer une position de recul vis-à-vis de son époque tout en s’en réclamant en partie dépositaire, de porter sur elle un regard critique sans la renier unilatéralement, de faire corps avec son temps sans nécessairement être solidaire de sa génération. Si mes cours portaient sur le Moyen Âge ou encore le XIXe siècle, je pourrais […] parler, engoncée dans mes propos, au nom d’un temps qui dépasse le temps. Mais alors que je m’attache à travailler sur ce que certains appellent non sans mépris et bêtise l’extrême contemporain, je m’aperçois que ce qui m’excite encore dans ce que j’enseigne, c’est de montrer à des étudiants des textes qui, en quelque sorte, n’appartiennent pas encore tout à fait à l’Histoire, mais qui font plutôt écho à ma petite histoire, à ma vie minuscule qui reste la seule chose que je peux léguer ou encore donner à entendre. (25–26) Ainsi, écrire sur le chaque jour, subjectiver l’actualité, c’est accepter qu’une icône galvaudée comme Michael Jackson, en mourant, fasse mourir avec lui une partie de ce que nous avons été, en deçà de ou par delà toute pertinence culturelle. Parce que la vie, pour se continuer, a à ne pas se renier. Parce qu’il a été le contemporain d’un désir qui n’était pas seulement le sien de ne jamais mourir.
Le temps est immensément cruel pour ceux et celles qui survivent à leur jeunesse. […] Et la cruauté des années réside dans ma propre humiliation, dans la ressemblance que je me découvre aujourd’hui avec Michael Jackson.
Or, c’est précisément d’humiliation qu’il est question dans l’enseignement de ce qui constitue le contemporain, ou le pas très ancien […] malgré ma volonté de rendre compte le plus objectivement d’une époque, établir une anthologie du présent ou du passé immédiat relève irrémédiablement du goût, du choix intime, de l’exhibition de soi et de son temps comme mortel. (29) Saisir son temps comme mortel, c’est aussi saisir sa vie dans son caractère fugitif, au présent, et de ce point de vue l’écriture du blogue constitue une ponctuation du monde. Le discours qu’il propose du chaque-jour ou du chaque-instant opère à la fois une conversion de l’empirique en matière à penser, mais aussi met en évidence le tissage de nos vies.

Dans un texte intitulé Moments fragiles, l’exemple du père du petit Eloi menant son fils à l’école chaque matin, mais qui un jour tout à coup pas comme les autres lui déclare qu’il l’aime, attire notre attention sur le fait que la vie est à reconquérir chaque jour, qu’elle est une conscience à saisir ou ressaisir, non un état naturel ou donné. Tous les matins, j’entends le père d’Éloi dire au revoir à son fils. […] Mais ce matin, le père d’Éloi […] a ajouté ce je t’aime qui m’a fait tressaillir. Il y a, il est vrai, dans tout au revoir à nos proches, une forme de déclaration d’amour secrète, cryptée, que parfois l’intonation révèle un peu. En disant à l’aimé : Au revoir, bonne journée! , nous lui donnons la permission de passer quelques heures sans nous, et nous maîtrisons un peu l’angoisse de la perte possible, de la mort qui se love, comme une traître, même dans les petites séparations.(116–117) Peur de la séparation, peur de la mort qui n’est pas l’apanage des mères, mais de quiconque voit le temps passer dans son enfant. La maternité, la paternité nous rappellent parfois que le temps doit s’arrêter (118). Or, Dans ce je t’aime, Éloi…, le père stoppait un peu la marche folle du temps; il volait un morceau d’enfance aux heures et aux années méchantes à venir et donnait à lui-même et à son fils la permission de s’oublier l’un l’autre, de faire avec la vie (117).

Alors si, selon un vieux mythe féministe, c’est la vie qui se transmet dans ces écrits quasi quotidiens d’une femme en prise sur l’actualité, dans la tradition du journal intime et dans la mythologie de la maternité qui donne le jour, ici c’est d’une vie comme travail qu’il s’agit, une vie comme rythme, comme inscription de soi dans le monde, à inventer chaque jour.

L’écriture du blogue, la forme de présentation et de diffusion spécifique de la page Internet d’un écrivain, devient alors un mode de pensée spécifique, à même d’intégrer le régime discontinu selon lequel nous vivons nos vies. À même aussi d’y refaire du lien : entre moi et le père de cet enfant, moi et mon voisin, moi et ma famille, moi et les millions de gens qui dans le monde souffrent en même temps que moi et, que sans connaître pourtant, je n’ignore pas.

p.ref: À la fois improvisé et né d’une nécessité, le blogue est pour notre présent ce papier d’un jour par lequel Marguerite Duras désignait la chronique d’un temps d’été voué plus encore qu’un autre à disparaître. Il est moins expression d’un moment sauvé brièvement de l’oubli qu’exposition de ce qui fait la matière même d’un jour, ce mélange de tâches et d’omission des sentiments les plus forts au milieu duquel surgit parfois un rêve ou une folie.

En empruntant la forme subalterne — et éminemment singularisée — d’un billet d’humeur ou d’une histoire exemplaire, Catherine Mavrikakis opère cette conversion de la matière du temps en matière à penser. Elle tire de ce tissu apparemment anodin, anecdotique, une réflexion de plus grande échelle qui dit quelque chose de l’organisation de valeurs souvent implicite qui sous-tend nos vies. Le blogue ne parle pas ainsi de l’actualité, mais donne son actualité au jour, pour celle qui l’écrit, pour ceux qui la lisent, et qui, la lisant, co-énoncent et co-actualisent un jour qui est peut-être aussi le leur (et pas nécessairement en même temps).

Le billet-page, la page-jour fabriquent ainsi un format énonciatif, un rythme ayant à voir avec le continu discontinu de nos vies; ils actualisent une rythmique intensive du vivre dont nous prenons rarement conscience. Ultimement donc, l’écriture du blogue, plus que celle du livre, affirme la mise en vivre du monde par sa mise en langage. L’écrit n’a plus seulement le rôle de graver dans la pierre, ou s’il le fait c’est justement en accéléré. Éternité en accéléré, le blogue fusionne la pérennité historique de l’écrit avec la vitesse d’exécution du vivre, rapprochant la possibilité d’être le contemporain de cette vie en action qui a conscience d’être en vie.

Marguerite Duras déplorait de ne pouvoir rejoindre, en tant qu’individu, celle-là, celle qui avait écrit ça (Interview 59)L’extrait dit encore : J’étais bouleversée par celle qui avait vu la mer, qui avait vu cet enfant, qui avait couru sur les collines d’argile, le long de la mer. J’étais dans un état de colère, comme ça, de la vie, que la vie vécue ne puisse pas rejoindre ça. J’étais jalouse de moi. (59)., faisant référence au sujet d’écriture de L’été 80 et à l’actualité singulière et décalée du présent de l’écriture, qui nous rend après coup (et, sans doute, sublime) le présent de la vie, toujours inconnu de soi pendant qu’il se vit. Catherine Mavrikakis écrit au plus vite, au plus près, pour que cette vie qui passe en s’ignorant, cette vie qui se vit en vitesse sans la conscience de mourir, se réfléchisse au double sens du terme, se retourne sur elle-même pour se voir exister. Proche en cela beaucoup plus du Journal de deuil de Roland Barthes que du journalisme, son écriture enregistre le vivre comme un mourir, comme un décompte du temps et la prise de conscience de ce peu de durée qui nous reste avant de disparaître. Écriture du présent, elle l’est seulement dans la mesure où elle montre à quel point le présent n’est accessible que rétrospectivement. Son but ultime, à l’instar du mérite d’exemplarité qu’elle prête au genre biographique, c’est de faire de la vie un savoir (Par l’exemple 178). Désir d’autant plus poignant que Mavrikakis déclare : Il y a quelque chose d’épuisant et surtout de terrorisant à ne pas pouvoir, à bientôt cinquante ans, m’appuyer sur l’expérience que j’ai arrachée au temps (Back-slide 25). L’écriture, a fortiori celle du blogue, permet peut-être de remédier à cette carence, par l’instauration, en lieu et place du partage d’expériences assurées et certaines, validées par le temps, d’un partage qui va pouvoir devenir expérience.

ref.ref: Le blogue, comme à sa manière la capsule de radioOn écoutera en particulier pour apercevoir cette saisie de vie qu’est l’entretien radiophonique l’émission enregistrée avec Savannah Lou, la fille de Catherine Mavrikakis. http://radiospirale.org/emission/revez-pour-moi., vient mettre de la conscience dans la fuite irraisonnée du temps. Beaucoup plus qu’un moyen technique, ce qu’apporte sa possibilité technologique est cette monstration du fugitif que signale également l’enregistrement des voix de la conversation : bien qu’on puisse les archiver, on ne peut les retenir. Une fois disparus les corps qui les portaient, ils deviennent les supports physiques indispensables d’une conscience du vivre, aussi bien que des rappels irrémédiablement nostalgiques.
